BE11:15am

2H & Multi-Yr Guidance Commentary Suggests No Quick Fix for Facebook.
Management provided both more detailed and longer-term guidance than is typical, each of which are below Street expectations. For Q3 & Q4, the company expects revenue growth rates to drop in the high single digit percentages each quarter, from the 42% y/y level reported in Q2. This would imply Q3 revenue growth in the low-to-mid 30s y/y (vs. consensus of 38%) and Q4 revenue growth in the mid-20s y/y (vs. consensus of 34%). Full year OPEX growth guidance remained unchanged at 50-60% y/y, but the company suggested that OPEX growth will remain higher than revenue in 2019. Looking longerterm, management's multi-year expectation for operating margin is that it will fall into the mid-30s in a "few" years (i.e. 2021). This implies a glide path downward that would put 2020 op margin at around 38-39% (we are modeling 38%), compared to previous consensus 2020 op margin of approx. 43-44%.

nightingale20201 morning all
BE11:15am

Three Primary Issues: GDPR, Stories and FX. Facebook cited three key items
impacting revenue that resulted in both the slight Q2 miss and the decelerating growth
outlook for Q3 & Q4. First, GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) in the EU was not fully rolled out in Q2, but creates some degree of "friction" with EU users who are asked to opt-in or out of allowing Facebook to track their web footprint for better ad targeting. We also believe the company will be reducing at least some forms of targeting functionality (especially 3P data) in Europe in 2H'18, which could reduce certain advertiser use-cases. Second, Facebook's promotion of "Stories" is pulling users away from their feed, which is a revenue negative as Stories currently has extremely low monetization. The longterm thinking is that Stories users are more highly engaged and will be better monetizing at some point, but in the near-term this is detrimental to the company's economics. And third, FX fluctuations have negatively impacted revenue growth rates and are now factored into (at current rates) the 2H revenue growth outlook.

BE11:18am

Here's Baird.

BE11:18am

Stories could help boost engagement. Given Facebook's emphasis on more
engaging content, particularly with video, promoting Stories in News Feed could
improve the durability of Facebook's revenue over the long term, and improve
engagement trends, which according to our surveys, have declined this year.
- Facebook knows what it's doing. Given that the pivot towards Stories
represents a material strategic shift from traditional newsfeed monetization, we
believe Facebook would not adopt this approach unless there was good visibility
for engagement lift.
- If Instagram serves as a guide, monetization can ramp VERY quickly. Less
than two years since launch, Instagram Stories now counts over 400M DAUs
(~2/3 of total DAUs), with a relatively quick ramp in monetization. This bodes well
for recovering revenue growth in 2019.

BE11:19am

Though the bear points are probably worth including as well.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Stories may not translate to Facebook given different mobile use cases. Instagram's exclusively
photo/video-oriented content lends better to Story consumption than Facebook's more eclectic mix
of text/link/photo/video content. As such, there's no gaurentree that more prominent Story placement
within News Feed will result in greater Story adoption/usage among core Facebook users, particularly
older demographics unfamiliar with the format. However, as highlighted above, we believe Facebook
has done some degree of testing around Story reception within core Facebook.
■ Shift to Stories could mask underlying engagement softness. Some investors may view the pivot
toward Story content as a referendum on the recent initiative to boost News Feed engagement through
other forms of community content (i.e. the News Feed algorithm tweaks announced over the past
year). We do not share this view, but given stagnant US/Europe DAU trends, this could be a focal
point for bears.
■ Investments in platform security accompanied by questions around model scalability. Given
concerns around safety/security and the "billions" of annual expenditures associated with monitoring
activity across 2.5B unique (i.e. de-duped) monthly users across all Facebook properties (Facebook,
Instagram, WhatsApp, Messenger), incremental margins are less attractive if manual review/input is
required to ensure community safety for the next billion users.

BE11:28am

For the fourth time in a row, Diageo has been able to deliver solid sales growth
combined with operating leverage and high cash generation, proving its high
quality compounder status in our view. While there is no earnings upgrade today
and Diageo trades on 21.7x CY19 P/E, we believe Diageo will continue to
overdeliver and has strong visibility on earnings. Diageo is relatively protected
from disruptive factors shaking up CPG and the potential tariffs threat between
EU and US has now disappeared which should support the stock.

BE11:29am

And Bernstein

BE11:29am

Diageo announced F18 results with solid underlying performance (apart from US spirits), and enhanced optimism for the business: the margin expansion guidance was maintained at 175bps together with the med term organic growth for the business at mid-single digits. In addition, the board approved at £2bn share buy-back to take place over the course of F19. F18 was overall broadly in-line with our expectations, with largest North America and Europe/Turkey broadly in-line with expectations. Associate (Moët Hennessey) came in a little low, with minorities also a touch softer.

BE11:32am

Diageo’s organic sales growth accelerated to 5.5% in 2H18 driven by acceleration in
North America, Latac and Asia Pacific. Versus consensus organic sales growth was
ahead for North America and Asia Pacific but was below for Europe, Africa and
Latac.
The company delivered organic operating margin expansion of 78bps (vs consensus
60bps) driven primarily by lower ‘other operating expenses’ despite a 43bps
reduction in gross margin and 27bps headwind from higher marketing spend. To
deliver higher margin expansion than expected despite a increase in marketing
spend is a positive result.
Implications
We expect the shares to react positively to the organic sales beat, the EPS beat and
the higher than anticipated buyback announcement which together more than offset
the reported operating profit miss. We would expect consensus EPS estimates to
modestly increase all else equal, and therefore expect a positive share price reaction

Hard reading from Jefferies:

BE11:38am

EPS at 137.2p, c2% ahead of cons. (Jeff 132.9p; cons 134.8p). Org. operating
performance ahead of our expectation. Vols (heated & cigs) were -2.2% (Jeff. -0.4%), sales 1.9% (Jeff 1.7%; cons. 2%), EBIT 2.4% (Jeff 1.4%), margins up 40bps (Jeff -36bps). EPS FX headwind FY18 guided at 5-6% (we are at 6.1%). Continues to believe it can exceed £1bn RRP sales. Heated gets approval US. Further commits to another good year of ex FX EPS growth (we take this as HSD).

Pharma @nichoman, and unicorns. Mustn't forget the unicorns.
Flaneur Anyone know who is working on upgrading the electricity transmission system in the UK?
jaws BE anything in Biogen US or Smith Nephew here please ?
11:40 am
BE11:40am

To like: 1. Robust organic sales delivery, in line with consensus. It was important that it hit or beat consensus here given that it still doesn’t have the contribution from heated really coming through [PM 1H18 sales at 8.3%]. If we adjust for the NAS inventory impact from last year then sales would have grown 2.6%.

Pharma @Flaneur, not sure on the hardware, but the Russians are busy updating the software systems.
BE11:41am

2) Better margin delivery than we had expected although we guess this is more to do with phasing of spending with much of this skewed to 2H18. We still expect FY18 margins to be down.

BE11:41am

3) Approval of its carbon tip heated tobacco cigarette in the US. This should help with RRP conviction and, importantly, means it will be first to the US market with a heated tobacco product (it already has one but it is the old version and is in very limited distribution). It remains to be seen how popular heated tobacco will be in the US but being first, and in a format we think will appeal more (a cigarette-like product as opposed to a device), positions it well.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Not to Like: 1) Pulling away from substantially more than £1bn in RRP sales. However, we think the fact it still hopes to exceed £1bn will be taken positively given the slowdown in Japan. Also, given that it did £427m in 1H18, we believe this will not prove too much of a stretch. 2) Cigarette volumes down 3.1% (we were expecting -1.2%). We believe this is likely more a function of the market slowdown but nonetheless it may cause some concern.

Flaneur @pharma - As Homer Simpson says 'Its funny because its true'...
BE11:42am

Counterpoint from Citi

BE11:42am

We think this print is marginally disappointing given the miss on
NGP sales and the weak volume. The acceleration in 2H profit relies on better price-mix, as opposed to a volume pickup. The good news is that this is broadly in BAT’s control; the bad news is volumes are likely to remain disappointing. The NGP guidance assumes an acceleration in 2H, driven by new launches, both in heated tobacco and in e-vapor, and there has to be some uncertainty around this.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

The lack of robust activity and inconsistent effect on traditional
cognitive measures makes it highly unlikely that BAN2401 could
be approved on this data in our view, and certainly leads us to
believe that BAN2401 is less robust than aducanumab at slowing
cognitive decline. Biogen’s comments suggest that aducanumab
remains the company’s preferred option in the early Alzheimer’s disease
population and we see a disconnect between Biogen’s caution and their
partner Eisai’s excitement about BAN2401. Based on the full topline data
disclosure we are not inclined to make additional changes to our forecast
for Biogen, and we currently do not include BAN2401 in our revenue
forecast, but estimate a 35% probability of success for aducanumab
being approved in 2021.

BE11:51am

Vesuvius reported strong 1H18 results, beating GS estimates for 1H18 EBIT by 3% and sales by 2%. Management have indicated in their guidance that they expect FY trading profit to be marginally above company compiled consensus estimates of £189m (GS: £190m). We note that Reuters/Bloomberg consensus is 2-3% below the company compiled estimate.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

OSG decelerated to 12.1% vs. 15.4% in 2H17 and both the Steel and Foundry
divisions saw c.3%pts in OSG, but both divisions posted double digit growth. Interestingly, Vesuvius achieved 6%pts of pricing growth (to offset raw materials), which may have also contributed to this sequential slowdown. Our analysts continue to expect 3-4% (ex. China) steel production growth and it is clear that Vesuvius is outgrowing its markets. In addition, management expectations for benefits in their latest restructuring program has increased to £22m (from £15m previously). Given Vesuvius’ share price has been almost flat over 3 months (increased 2% vs. the sector flat), we expect a positive share price reaction.

A 5.6% fall in like-for-like values over the six months has
reduced NAV per share by 12% to 362p. We remain concerned
around the valuation of “prime” retail assets – the 33bp increase
in Intu’s topped-up initial yield should be the start of the repricing,
and not the end. With LTV approaching 50%, further
re-pricing will have a meaningful impact on net assets and we
downgrade our Dec 2018 forecast by 20%. The prevailing deep
discount does not adequately reflect the risks, in our view.
